The course will then consider Wittgenstein's critique of the Tractatus at the beginning of the Investgations, and explore his account of language, his philosophical methods, and his detailed explorations of the grammar of human psychology. The Brics and Its Future: the View from Russia
The Brics and Its Future: the View from Russia

The course investigates the contemporary state of the BRICS constellation and its outlines taking into account world challenges. For the last decade a few BRICS summits took place, and the organization has passed through the political and economic self-determination confirming the prospects of its geographical expansion. In the meantime, the perspectives of the BRICS development seem to be blurred due many circumstances. Most pivotal of them are different international interests of the BRICS countries which generate a whole spectrum of political and economic problems and negatively influences cooperation within this community. It strongly affects national priorities of all the BRICS countries including Russia which seems to be an outsider against a neighboring China and gradually is lagging behind India. A comparative analysis of the positions of these countries is one of the pivotal tasks for the author. The conclusions in this regard to be made seem to be intriguing and even provocative. During the course Strovskytends to raise not only the problematic issues of the political and economic linkage between the BRICS countries but also the problems of the media involvement in the BRICS agenda. A special attention is being paid to information globalization and its effects on media matters. A survey conducted for 2012-2016 years by the group of media experts from the BRICS countries including the author himself is under Strovsky’s grave investigation. These priorities make the course attractive for the students from different studying programs of Sichuan university.
The Media in Terms of Modern International Globalization.
The Media in Terms of Modern International Globalization.

International globalization in the contemporary world is a very specific phenomenon originated historically and currently involving all countries into its orbit. Globalization affects the world politically, economically, socially and spiritually which creates unequal opportunities for the development of different countries. The author sorts out the evolution of this process stemming from the old times and finishing with the post-industrial era. Under his investigation are pros and cons of globalization. A significant part of Strovsky’s course is devoted to the media involvement into globalization trends. The role of the media looks extremely important in these conditions. On the one hand, they seem to be subordinated to the frameworks of this process due to their dependence on most pivotal decisions of the day; on the other one, the media themselves look as the moderators and even provocateurs of the global agenda. Different media theories being illustrative to this ‘double background’ are supposed to be envisaged. A special attention is paid to the media role in terms of political transformation and conflicts in some leading countries including Russia, China, the US and some others. Within this context, the author tends to demonstrate a direct dependence of the media on contemporary political priorities on the national and international levels. The course is focused on many theoretical frameworks but also examines practical situations concerning the politics/economics/media relationships which are likely to stimulate world view of the students.
The Enlightenment: Science of Society from Hobbes to Hegel
The Enlightenment: Science of Society from Hobbes to Hegel

The course aims at providing an insight into the central theoretical foundations of the modern (mainly Western) account of society in their historical context. It aims to make students understand how European thinkers developed their theories of society and human agency in response to religious wars, global commerce, as well as massive social inequalities of wealth and status. In a close study of some cardinal texts in European thought, such as Hobbes, Rousseau, Adam Smith, and Kant, we will discuss ideas of toleration, natural rights, division of labour, human equality, progress, reform, republicanism, legal order, and aesthetic education. These concepts still form the bread and butter of modern political theory and students will understand the limitations as well as the theoretical achievements of these ideas.

This course will survey economic theory from antiquity through the origins of market capitalism in order to identify the peculiar philosophical assumptions underlying how we understand economics, such as assumptions regarding human nature, or how flourishing and economics were originally related. We will engage with some of the most influential concepts that still shape our lives and underpin our economic systems. They include, e.g., the concepts of alienation or the ‘invisible hand’ as a market-regulating principle, and also how economics was originally seen as being determined by the common good. We will also examine arguments at to how capitalism became the dominant economic system and how the social and economic systems we live in may influence the way we think. Texts from key thinkers such as, e.g., Aristotle, Smith, Mill, Marx and Weber will be discussed and examined and whether their ideas can provide a basis for solutions for contemporary issues.

This course will investigate the concept of toleration, its importance but also its limits. We will start with a brief historical introduction, looking in particular at Nicholas of Cusa and John Locke as two exemplary thinkers illustrating how European thinkers tried to respond to the political-religious conflicts of their time, by using toleration as a means to engage with otherness in a peaceful manner while at the same time also emphasizing the limits of toleration. We will then proceed to examine different contemporary concepts of toleration, using the ideas of the political theorist Rainer Forst as a foundation. We will finish by looking at some contemporary philosophical reflections on the necessity of limits of toleration such as Ku？andi and Ricoeur.

This course will consider Hume’s writings on religion, which are a major critique of religionas such and of all attempts to provide philosophical proofs for the existence of God.Particular consideration will be given to Hume’s classic texts on the matter, The NaturalHistory of Religion and the Dialogues Concerning Natural Religion.The Dialogues ask if belief in God can be inferred from the nature of the universe orwhether it is even consistent with what we know about religion. The Natural Historyof Religion investigates the origins of belief, and follows its development fromharmless polytheism to dogmatic monotheism. It is widely recognized that these twoworks constitute the most formidable attack on the rationality of religious belief evermounted by a philosopher.

Assuch, friendship is undoubtedly central to our lives, in part because the special concernwe have for our friends must have a place within a broader set of concerns, includingmoral concerns, and in part because our friends can help shape who we are as persons.Given this centrality, important questions arise concerning the justification offriendship …”. This course will examine the views of some of the major Westernphilosophers on this topic as well as the recurring problem of reconciling the demandsand duties of friendship when there conflict between friendships and public and privatemorality.

This course will provide undergraduate students with a substantial introduction into the philosophic foundations and the evolving institutional and behavioral practices of American government since its founding. While this course will cast a broad net covering much of American government, among those themes that will receive a lion’s share of attention none seems more deserving than the work of the Founding Fathers of American government. Their thoughts about human nature and government, and the influence that thinkers like Locke and Montesquieu had on America’s “Founding Generation” will be critically reviewed, inviting comparisons between the original design and the present operation of American political institutions. This comparison will be enlivened by frequent references to original framing documents—e.g., the Federalist Papers, and selected writings of Jefferson—and bedrock decisions of the Supreme Court over the course of the Republic’s life. Additional topics that shall be scrutinized include: the powers of, and relationships among, our three branches of government; federalism and its strengths and weaknesses in contemporary America; and the growing influence of the bureaucracy—America’s 4th branch of government—in the policymaking process. The book on which this course will be grounded is Peter Woll’s American Government: Readings and Cases; now in its 19th edition, Woll has managed to gather an outstanding collection of original source material from which underlying principles about the nature of American government can be appreciated, and about which fascinating questions can be raised and debated.

China and Russia: four centuries of the relationship: realities, problems and outlines

The course will introduce students to current issues in international relations. The themes will be multilateralism and multipolarity, as alternatives to unipolar or bipolar global power structures The courset will concentrate on the relations between China, Europe and the US each with their own history and values. It will look at how each approaches globalization. In particular, on the issues of trade, environment, security, information society, international organizations (UN, WTO) etc. Part of the focus will be on how domestic politics and institutions influences foreign policy. In view of the rise of populism in the US and EU the course will look at the potential for instability in global relations and how populists influence relations with China.In the second part of the course attention will be given to the development of relations between China and Europe and how these might evolve in relation to US nationalistic policies. The potential for China and Europe to cooperate in order to strengthen global order will be examined. Both China and Europe seem to be developing policies based on the concept of regional globalism. The potential of this concept will be discussed.Students will be encouraged to express their own views and national perspectives especially in relation to the historic events which have shaped international relations in the 21st century. Such events would include World War Two and the foundation of the UN and EU. The foundation of the PRC and China’s growing global status. The Cold War. 9/11 and the issues of terrorism, immigration, refugee crisis which have contributed to instability in the Middle East and Europe will also be examined. 哲学作为文科基础素质教育的基础，对大学生思想启蒙与思维训练具有重要意义。但是专业性的哲学知识讲解容易让非专业学生产生倦怠感。然而，训练学生带有批判性的思维模式与激励他们保持对世界的好奇心，对其未来的成长将非常重要。某种意义上，通识教育的目的也在此。如何能够在艰深枯燥的理论讲授中找出一条启迪学生自我学习、自我探索的道路，如何能够激励他们对思想观和方法论的兴趣，这是这门课程想要尝试解决的问题。如果能够以生动有趣的方式做好哲学导论的教授，则对素质教育的实现方法和路径都会有所裨益。本课程旨在生动直观地向学生展示哲学问题的实质以及正确的分析方法。本课程尝试以电影作为媒介导出哲学问题，让学生在轻松的氛围中由浅入深进入哲学理论的学习与思考中。最终，希望激发他们的哲学思维，提升其批判性思考的能力。
本课程将传统哲学问题分为存在论、认识论、社会问题及现代性反思四个部分。在每一部分中，以问题为导向提取出数个分问题。同时，选择能够体现这些问题所涉及的问题域，并在其中展现出问题产生争论的关键环节的电影，引导学生进入相关问题的学习。

医事法学是专门研究和探讨与医疗事务相关的法律体系、法律理论和法律制度的学科，面向本科学生（尤其是医科学生）开设。通过医事法学的学习，可以了解和掌握我国医事法律法规的基本体系，培养学生的职业法律思维能力，提高学生的职业法律意识。课程力图将知识的传授与实践能力的培养有机的结合起来，在坚持体系化讲授医事法学知识的同时，积极引入“以问题为导向”的学习方式和案例教学方法。医事法学是一门实践性很强的学科。以案例教学法（CBL）为基本手段，本课程将把当前医疗实践中产生的一些重大、疑难法律案例引入课堂，通过小组讨论、班级讨论等多种教学方式鼓励学生积极探讨解决途径，引导学生形成法律的思维方式，培养学生运用医事法解决执业实践问题的能力。

解码国家安全（国际关系学院）

习近平总书记指出：“当前我国国家安全内涵和外延比历史上任何时候都要丰富，时空领域比历史上任何时候都要宽广，内外因素比历史上任何时候都要复杂”，“只有国家安全和社会稳定，改革发展才能不断推进”，为此，国家安全事关国家政权、主权、统一和领土完整、人民福祉、经济社会可持续发展等国家核心利益。全体人民，特别是可能成为国家安全专业队伍潜在人力资源的大学生，了解国家安全基本知识，正确认识中国国家安全形势与挑战，不断提高国家意识和国家安全管理能力，对于维护国家安全具有重要的意义。

1）传授国家安全基本知识，培养学生国家安全意识；
2）提升学生甄别危害国家安全行为和事件的能力；
3) 引导学生履行维护国家安全的义务，使人生更有意义、更有价值。

为深化习近平新时代中国特色社会主义思想和党的十九大精神的学习宣传贯彻，更好地回答当代大学生在学习贯彻过程中遇到的热点难点问题，讲好新时代中国故事，传播新时代中国声音，凝聚新时代中国力量，切实把广大学生的思想和行动统一到党的十九大确定的目标任务上来，我们在深入调研论证的基础上，凝聚全校文科知名专家学者开设《中国新时代》这门通识教育模块课程。该课程以习近平新时代中国特色社会主义思想为指导，梳理出8个方面的重大理论和实践问题，紧密联系新时代中国特色社会主义的生动实践，紧密联系广大学生的思想实际，争取对这些问题作出深入浅出的解读阐释，不断增强当代大学生对中国特色社会主义的道路自信、理论自信、制度自信和文化自信，切实推动习近平新时代中国特色社会主义思想和党的十九大精神“进教材、进课堂、进学生头脑”。
